Dow Chemical Corporation has prepared this Risk Management Plan (RMP) Update for the Dow Chemical Torrance Distribution Terminal in accordance with Section 2745.10 of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  In accordance with paragraph (a) of this section, the update has been prepared within 5 years of the date of the original submittal.  [The plan was last submitted to the Torrance Fire Department (the Administering Agency) in June 1999.]
The following activities were conducted in support of the RMP Update, in accordance with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP guidance for updates: 

A three-year compliance audit was conducted by an outside environmental contractor, in accordance with Section 2760.8 of the CalARP regulations.

The Offsite Consequence Analysis was revised using a current version of RMP*Comp¿.  The affected population and list of sensitive receptors was revised using current population data and other resources.
The seismic analysis for the affected systems was reviewed for changes to the system, changes to the building codes that may impact affected systems, and implementation of recommendations made in the last seismic review.

In addition, Dow Chemical has revised the Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) for the facility using a proprietary technique.

The facility has changed ownership since the previous RMP was submitted and many of the various plans and programs referenced in the RMP have been revised.  Dow has prepared a new RMP registration submittal to reflect these changes to the RMP.

ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY

Dow Chemical Corporation has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  Dow is committed to operating and maintaining all of the processes in a safe and responsible manner.  Dow has implemented a combination of accident release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of its employees and the public, as well as

to protect the environment.  These programs include both Dow Chemical¿s Responsible Care® requirements and governmental requirements, such as the EPA¿s RMP program and the CalARP RMP program.  The objective is to minimize the risk of a release of a hazardous material, and if a release occurs, to minimize the potential impact to employees, the public, and the environment.  Dow Chemical management is committed to providing appropriate training to employees, and coordinating response activities, as necessary, with the local emergency response providers.

DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The facility is located at 19500 Mariner Avenue in the City of Torrance, California.  The facility is known as the Torrance Distribution Terminal.  The activities conducted at the facility include the bulk storage, transfer and blending of chemicals.  Tank cars are temporarily stationed on-site for the unloading of bulk chemicals.  The Torrance terminal is recognized as a covered source under the RMP rule as the facility maintains quantities of a regulated substance above the threshold quantities listed in the RMP rule.  Currently, the only regulated substance present on-site in quantities above the threshold limit is vinyl acetate monomer (VAM).

Annual VAM throughput is approximately 43 million pounds.  VAM is received by tank rail cars and stored in one aboveground tank, Tank 26, dedicated for storage of VAM.  (In addition, VAM can also be received by tank truck, but there are currently no plans to use this mode of receipt.) Tank 26 is described below.
Internal floating roof tank with double deck pontoon rim seals.
265,000-gallon maximum capacity and 186,000-gallon operating capacity (using administrative controls);
Secondary containment with a capacity of over 350,000 gallons; and
 Floating gauge for measuring liquid level.
VAM is transferred via pipeline to the adjacent UCAR® Emulsion Systems (UES) latex manufacturing plan as needed or is shipped to customers

via tank trucks.  Trucks are vented to a scrubber during loading to control the release of vapors.  If VAM is loaded directly from rail cars to trucks, a dedicated vapor balance system is used to reduce emissions to the atmosphere.  At present, 100 percent of the Terminal¿s VAM is transferred to the UCAR Emulsions Systems facility via pipeline, and there are no plans to resume shipment to customers by tank truck.

A network of product transfer piping is routed between the VAM storage, the truck loading station and the adjacent UES latex plant.  All piping is coated to prevent corrosion and is supported by steel framework, or is securely fastened to concrete or asphalt platforms or foundations.  Underground sections of piping (two road crossings) are encased by an outer pipe to prevent corrosion due to contact with soils.

 HAZARD ASSESSMENT

RMP regulations require that each facility identify worst-case and alternative case release scenarios.  EPA has defined a worst-case release as the release of the entire contents of the largest vessel that contains a regulated substance in a 10-minute period.  EPA defines alternative release scenarios as scenarios that are more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario, and that reaches an endpoint offsite, unless no such scenario exists.  One or more alternative release scenarios are evaluated to define the distance to the specified endpoint.  Unless otherwise specified, no credit was taken for administrative controls or active mitigation measures in evaluating the off-site impact of the scenarios.

The zones of potential impact for the worst-case and alternative release were predicted using RMP*Comp¿ (Version 1.07) released by the EPA.  RMP*Comp¿ is an electronic tool to make the same calculations as performed manually by following the procedures described in EPA¿s guidance document, RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance (April, 1999).

Worst-Case Release Scenario

The worst-case release scenario involves derailment of

a railcar and subsequent release of the entire railcar contents.  A passive mitigation measure in place is coarse gravel along the rail spur. The surface area of the resultant pool was estimated assuming a pool depth of 3 inches to reflect the reduction in horizontal extent of the pooled VAM due to percolation into the gravel.  The worst-case meteorological conditions defined by EPA for the worst-case release are a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second (m/s) and a stability class of F (very stable).  The liquid is assumed to be at a temperature of 77oF.  The distance to the threshold concentration of 0.26 mg/l is 1.9 miles (3,100 meters).  Approximately 87,400 persons reside within the 1.9-mile impact radius.  

The catastrophic failure of a railcar while on a siding is a very low probability event.  Over the ten year period 1991-2000, there were on average only 72 serious incidents per year in the United States in which hazardous material was released from a railcar during an incident or accident (U.S. DOT, Hazardous Materials Safety, Hazardous Materials Information System, 1/23/02).  Most of these incidents involved derailments and other energetic events that have high potential for causing a release of hazardous material.  A slowly moving or static railcar on a siding is rarely exposed to the energetic forces required to produce a catastrophic breach of the rail car tank. 

[Note: The catastrophic failure of the VAM storage tank was evaluated as a potential for the worst-case release.  However, due to the presence of the secondary containment area, which limits the surface area of a spill, and consequently the emission rate, the zone of impact for this release scenario was not as large as the rail car failure described above.]

 Alternative Release Scenario

The more likely alternative release scenario consists of a valve leak in the piping leading to Tank 26 caused by a stoppage of railcar unloading producing a liquid hammer that damages the valve.  The release ra

te is 250 gpm based on the pump capacity and is assumed to continue for 10 minutes prior to shutoff.  The release is contained within the tank¿s concrete containment area.  The calculated endpoint distance for the alternative scenario is based on typical meteorological conditions (3 m/s wind speed and D atmospheric stability).  No active mitigation measures are assumed and dispersion is based on an urban environment.  The distance to the endpoint concentration of 0.26 mg/l is 0.4 miles (600 meters).

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 

The Torrance Distribution Terminal¿s general accident prevention program consists of compliance with the following rules, as well as implementation of Dow Chemical¿s Operational Safety Program and Episodic Risk Management System.
California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program
40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention (RMP rule)
40 CFR Part 112, Spill Prevention, Control and Countermeasure
40 CFR Part 264, Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan
40 CFR Part 355, Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA)
The following is a brief outline of the general accident prevention program in place at the Torrance Distribution Terminal.

Compliance Audits

In accordance with Section 2760.8 of the CalARP regulations, a three-year compliance audit was conducted by an outside environmental contractor, ENSR Corporation, using a modified EPA RMP audit protocol.  The audit report is included in Appendix E.  The following deficiencies were noted during the audit:
The RMP lacked a Process Flow Diagram (PFD) for affected processes,
The dates of the most recent revisions of the various plans and programs were not current,
The facility contact information listed in the RMP registration documents was not current (due to change of ownership), and 
The OCA required revisions due to changes in the risk evaluation model and the population density and location of sensitive

receptors in the potential zone of impact from a worst-case release.

Each of these deficiencies has been addressed in this RMP Update.  The PFD is attached in Appendix A.  The revised OCA is attached in Appendix C, and the dates of the plan revisions and facility contact information are provided in the registration included in Appendix F.
In addition, to help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly Dow Chemical periodically conducts corporate and plant-led audits to ensure the process operations comply with governmental and Dow Chemical requirements.

Contractor Safety Program

Dow Chemical uses contractors to supplement its¿ work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Due to the fact that some contractors work on or near process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform facility personnel of any hazards that are found during their work.

Employee Participation 

Dow Chemical encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. Employees have access to all information created as part of the facility accident prevention program. Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained at the facility and addresses each accident prevention program element. In addition, employees participate in keeping process safety information up to date by making periodic inspections, having an active role in writing operating procedures and being involved in many other aspects of the accident prevention program, such as incident investigations. 

Episodic Risk Management System 

Periodic

reviews are conducted to identify hazards that could have significant community impact and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their occurrence. These reviews utilize advanced quantitative risk assessment techniques. 

 Equipment Design 

Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are designed according to recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements. 

Incident Investigation 

Dow Chemical promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury. The goal of each investigation is to determine the root cause of the incident by reviewing facts and developing corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. 

Management of Change 

Dow Chemical has a comprehensive system to ensure that modified facilities and processes will be safe to operate. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. 

Mechanical Integrity 

Dow Chemical has well-established practices and procedures to maintain tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, transfer hoses, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition. The basic aspects of this program include: (1) developing written procedures, (2) conducting training, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment. 

Operating Procedures 

Dow Chemical maintains written procedures that provide detail on how to safely operate a process, including various modes of process operations, such as unit startup, normal operation

s, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, normal shutdown, and initial startup of a new process. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate. The procedures are maintained up-to-date by revising them as necessary. 

Operational Safety Program 

Dow Chemical has a comprehensive program to ensure that all the elements listed within this accidental release prevention program are implemented at every Dow Chemical location. This Program includes accountabilities for timely and proper implementation of the program elements. 

Operational Safety Standards 

Design requirements for active and passive mitigation controls used to prevent major process hazards are documented in operational safety standards. 

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) 

Dow Chemical conducts reviews just prior to startup to ensure that new and modified facilities and processes are safe for operation. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented. 

Process Hazard Analysis 

Dow conducted an internal audit of the Torrance Distribution Terminal in 2002.  A PHA was conducted during the audit using Dow¿s proprietary ¿Reactive Chemical Process Hazard Analysis¿ (RCPHA).  RCPHA Software version 4.0 (Revised 1/10/01) was used in the review.  The principal staff performing the RCPHA was Kevin Wees and Al Fedoruk.  

The RCPHA methodology consists of a checklist designed by Dow for use in internal reactive chemical and PHA audits.  Table 1 lists the major topic addressed in the RCPHA questionnaire.  For each question in the questionnaire, there are columns for a yes/no/not applicable response, a response column, columns to check the work discipline affected, and an action item column.  In

addition to the RCPHA questionnaire, there is a second questionnaire that is used for field validation to be used in conjunction with the RCPHA.
The RCPHA audit of the Torrance Terminal was performed on May 21-22, 2002.  This RCPHA audit is an update to the PHA/Hazard Operability Study (HazOp) performed for the original Risk Management Prevention Program (RMPP) plan and the current RMP prepared in 1999.  The RCPHA report is included in Appendix B.

There have been no significant changes to the VAM process at the Torrance Terminal since the preparation of the previous RMP and PHA.  While truck loading of VAM is not now occurring, the facility retains the equipment and the capability to distribute VAM via tank truck.  Currently, 100 percent of VAM at the terminal is received by railcar and is delivered by pipeline to the adjoining Dow UCAR Emulsions Systems facility. 

As part of the RMP Update, the RCPHA developed during the May 2002 audit was reviewed by ENSR for completeness and applicability.   There were no significant findings identified during the RCPHA or during ENSR¿s review of the RCPHA.  All action items established during the RCPHA audit have been assigned for follow-up by the Terminal Manager.

External Events Analysis

ENSR International reviewed the seismic assessment portion of the Risk Management and Prevention Program (RMPP) seismic assessment conducted in December 1995 and updated in October 1999 for the Union Carbide Torrance Distribution Terminal.  After the review, ENSR conducted a walkthrough at the Terminal to confirm whether modifications recommended in the initial assessment and update had been completed.

The 1995 RMPP seismic assessment of the Terminal included the following areas: rail car offloading area, tanker truck loading area, vinyl acetate storage tank, and associated piping and pumps.  The supplemental seismic review was performed in 1999 to evaluate the Terminal according to the requirements in the 1998 Guidance for CalARP Seismic Assessment.

Based on a review of the recommendations provided in the 1995 and 1999 seismic assessments, and a walkthrough of the facility, it appears that the recommended modifications have been adequately implemented.  No additional areas of concern were identified during ENSR's walkthrough.
In addition, the PHA is supplemented with an external events analysis that addresses additional possible mechanisms for system failure.  No recommendations are made as a result of the

analysis.  The External Events Analysis is included in Appendix D.

Process Safety Information 

Dow Chemical keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, maintained up-to-date and available to operating personnel. 

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs). For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, pressure and level control) in the Operational Safety Standard (OSS) documents. The facility ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, automated operating systems, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems). 

The facility maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a means for establishing inspection and maintenance activities. 

Safe Work Practices 

Dow Chemical has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety. Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a hot work permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities, and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space. These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations

and maintenance activities are performed safely. 

Training/Certification Programs 

To complement the written procedures for process operations, Dow Chemical has implemented a comprehensive training and certification program for all employees involved in operating a process. After employees demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are certified to work independently. In addition, trained technical staff is available 24 hours a day to support operations. 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

In the last five years there has not been an accident or incident involving an CalARP RMP chemical at the Torrance Distribution Terminal that resulted in an on-site death, injury, or property damage; or a known off-site death, injury, evacuation, shelter-in-place, property damage or environmental damage. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION 

The Torrance Distribution Terminal maintains a written emergency response program to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of hazardous substances, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including: 
Proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, 
Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, 
Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public,
Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements (if a release occurs), and 
Inspecting, testing, maintaining, and using emergency response equipment. 
The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties. 

The overall emergency response program for Dow Chemical in Torrance is coordin

ated with the Torrance Fire Department and Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). Dow Chemical conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the emergency response organizations. In addition, Dow Chemical's Hazardous Emergency Leaks Prevention (HELP) team located in Torrance responds to accidental releases from transportation incidents occurring in the continental U.S. 

The emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations. Detailed emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Torrance Fire Department.
